G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the property that is the subject of this action is located within the judicial district served by this Court, and because the acts or omissions complained of occurred there.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the property that is the subject of this action is located within the judicial district served by this Court, and because the acts or omissions complained of occurred there.

G.L. c. 258E.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 258E, and the amount in controversy ($1,200) falls within this Court’s jurisdictional limit.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises, or who fails to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable and substantial interference by other tenants, violates the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6C.proposition: Award Plaintiff interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6C;

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees that a tenant shall not be substantially disturbed in the use and enjoyment of leased premises by the landlord or by others whose conduct the landlord could reasonably control.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment and explains that it protects tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy caused either by the landlord’s own conduct or by conditions the landlord has a duty and ability to prevent. The court rejects the landlord’s argument that it was not responsible for flooding caused by other tenants, holding that the landlord is liable where the interference is a preventable situation within its duty to control, thereby aligning with the proposition that quiet enjoyment covers disturbances by others whom the landlord could reasonably control.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … As its third objection … Gem asserts that it was wrongly held responsible for the actions of third parties beyond its control…. The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees that a tenant shall not be substantially disturbed in the use and enjoyment of leased premises by the landlord or by others whose conduct the landlord could reasonably control.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where substantial interference with tenants’ use arises from activities of others (here, a lounge) that are the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s leasing decisions and that the landlord has the right and ability to control. The opinion emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling and that tenants need not look solely to the third-party operator when the landlord could reasonably control the disturbance. This directly aligns with the proposition that quiet enjoyment protects against substantial disturbances by the landlord or by others whose conduct the landlord could reasonably control.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… We conclude that, as matter of law, the landlords had a right to control the objectionable noise coming from the lounge… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent….”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to take such steps constitute an indirect interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord’s inaction in the face of serious third‑party misconduct on common areas it controls can constitute a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion explains that if the housing authority “failed to take any action” or took “inadequate action” to remove nontenants engaged in unlawful activity, and that failure results in serious interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment, the landlord may be liable under the quiet enjoyment statute. This directly supports the proposition that a defendant’s failure and refusal to take steps can amount to an indirect interference with quiet enjoyment under § 14.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The issue on which our decision turns, then, is whether this serious interference with the tenancy of the plaintiffs is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done. … We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to take such steps constitute an indirect interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that the landlords’ failure to provide heat constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, regardless of their financial inability. However, the court does not frame this as an ‘indirect’ interference, nor does it analyze a failure or refusal to take remedial steps as an indirect interference; it treats the non‑provision of heat itself as the actionable interference. Thus, the case supports liability under § 14 for failing to furnish heat, but not specifically the characterization of that failure as an ‘indirect’ interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14….”

*Winchester v. O'Brien*, 266 Mass. 33 (1.proposition: The interference experienced by Plaintiff has been both substantial and ongoing, depriving her of her lawful right to the use and enjoyment of her home.
*Winchester v. O'Brien*, 266 Mass. 33 (1.support_reasoning: The court expressly finds that the landlord’s remodeling activities caused a “substantial and continued interference” with the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises, despite the tenant’s remaining in possession. While this is a commercial office rather than a residence, the legal principle is the same: ongoing, substantial interference that deprives a tenant of the comfortable and beneficial use of the premises supports a claim for relief. Thus, the opinion supports the proposition that substantial and ongoing interference can deprive a person of lawful use and enjoyment of their home or tenancy.
*Winchester v. O'Brien*, 266 Mass. 33 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Even though the work was carried on in a reasonable and proper manner and entirely outside the rooms leased, injury was done to the property and appliances used in those rooms; there were interruptions of the electric and water service therein, the plaintiff’s right of access was made more difficult, his property was injured, and he suffered a loss of income in business. … It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises and appurtenant rights by the acts done or authorized by the defendants…”

*Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott*, 312 Mas.proposition: The interference experienced by Plaintiff has been both substantial and ongoing, depriving her of her lawful right to the use and enjoyment of her home.
*Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott*, 312 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses constructive eviction and holds that the landlord’s failure to remedy smoke, soot, and fumes that entered the tenant’s apartment over a “substantial period of time” deprived the tenant of the use and enjoyment of the premises, excusing further rent. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s acts and omissions created conditions that rendered the apartment unfit and that these conditions persisted until the tenant vacated, thus recognizing substantial and ongoing interference with lawful use and enjoyment of the home.
*Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott*, 312 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The conditions that manifested themselves at once were not corrected by the landlord during the substantial period of time during which, the judge could and did find, they continued unabated. … [W]e are of opinion that the landlord must be presumed to have intended the natural consequences of its own acts, subsequent to the installation of the oil burner, in failing to remedy the conditions which deprived the tenant of the use and enjoyment of the premises over a substantial period of time, and that the judge was warranted … in concluding that the tenant had been evicted by the landlord.”

*Doe v. Cooperative Cent. Bank*, 426 Mas.proposition: The interference experienced by Plaintiff has been both substantial and ongoing, depriving her of her lawful right to the use and enjoyment of her home.
*Doe v. Cooperative Cent. Bank*, 426 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal homicide case about murder, intoxication, Miranda waivers, and jury instructions; it does not concern private nuisance, interference with property, or a plaintiff’s right to use and enjoy her home. There is no discussion of substantial or ongoing interference with residential property or any analogous civil doctrine. Therefore it does not provide authority for the stated proposition about deprivation of use and enjoyment of a home.

*Fitzgerald v. Congleton*, 155 Mass. 155.proposition: The interference experienced by Plaintiff has been both substantial and ongoing, depriving her of her lawful right to the use and enjoyment of her home.
*Fitzgerald v. Congleton*, 155 Mass. 155.case_name: Fitzgerald v. Connecticut River Paper Co.
*Fitzgerald v. Congleton*, 155 Mass. 155.support_reasoning: The case concerns an employee’s personal injury from slipping on icy steps and addresses employer negligence and the doctrine of voluntary assumption of risk. It does not involve nuisance, property rights, or interference with use and enjoyment of a home, nor does it discuss any ongoing or substantial interference with residential property. Therefore, it does not support the proposition about substantial, ongoing deprivation of the use and enjoyment of a home.
*Fitzgerald v. Congleton*, 155 Mass. 155.relevant_excerpt: "There was evidence proper for the consideration of the jury on the question whether the defendant corporation was negligent in permitting the steps on which the plaintiff was injured to be slippery and dangerous. It was its duty to provide on its premises a reasonably safe passageway for the use of its employees in going to and from their work... We are of opinion that it cannot be said, as matter of law, that the plaintiff in the present case, in attempting to go down the steps, voluntarily assumed a risk..."

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: The harm suffered by Plaintiff falls squarely within the statute’s protection and entitles her to the actual and statutory damages set forth in G.L. c. 186, § 14, as well as reasonable attorney’s fees and costs, (although Plaintiff is pro se).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The case holds that a bare statutory violation (here, the lead paint statute) does not automatically constitute a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that at least negligent conduct plus notice or reason to know is required to trigger § 14 remedies, including attorney’s fees. It also emphasizes that the lead paint statute itself does not provide attorney’s fees and rejects using § 14 to obtain indirectly what the lead statute does not provide. Thus, the decision does not say that any harm within a statute’s protection automatically entitles a plaintiff to § 14 actual and statutory damages and attorney’s fees (especially not for a pro se litigant).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. … Significantly, the [lead paint] statute makes no provision for the payment of attorney’s fees; had the Legislature intended that attorney’s fees be awarded to a tenant who proves a violation of the lead paint statute it could readily have done so. … The plaintiffs cannot obtain indirectly what the statute fails to provide directly.”
